title: Livestock and livelihoods webinar series: Crossroads of animal human and environment health

subtasks: Greet participants via Zoom and ask for full names and organizations.
Enable closed captioning for the webinar.
Instruct attendees to keep microphones off when not speaking.
Remind participants to use the chat for questions and comments.
Acknowledge the recording and live tweeting.

tasks.task: Setting the Context for One Health (0:25 - 5:30)**
subtasks: Present a video on land use policy impacts on wildlife and livestock.
Explain the consequences of land privatization on biodiversity and health.
Introduce One Health principles for integrated land management.

tasks.task: Discussing Livestock Research and One Health (5:30 - 13:20)**
subtasks: Highlight the importance of livestock research in addressing global challenges like population growth and zoonotic diseases.
Emphasize the need for data generation, local capacity building, and surveillance systems.
Describe the role of vaccines and interventions in disease control.
Explain the process of scaling One Health through institutionalization and horizontal expansion.
Present examples of vertical scaling in platforms and research institutions.
Discuss challenges in scaling, such as funding, conceptualization, and community engagement.

tasks.task: Practical Examples of One Health Implementation (20:50 - 33:10)**
subtasks: Describe a USDA-funded project in Georgia focusing on market system development and food safety.
Explain the use of trainings, education materials, and animated videos in capacity building.
Highlight content from educational materials on veterinary medicines and sustainable practices.
Introduce the Linking Green and Rangeland Management project for pastoral communities.
Describe participatory range land management and the integration of livestock, human, and environmental health.
Explain the Grazing and Mutual Health System (GMHS) and its impact on livestock disease distribution.
Address questions from attendees regarding stakeholder reconciliation, capacity building, and disease prevention.
Address challenges in incorporating environmental health into One Health practices.
Discuss the role of market demand and consumer education in promoting One Health.
Share resources for further learning on One Health and livestock research.
